Scene: HBO title
Opening Credits / Title Sequence
Preparation for the trial
Loras confesses to his sins
Comparison:
In the books, Loras was never arrested and put on trial, nor did he ever join the Faith. He was sent by Cersei to conquer Dragonstone, where he was gravely injured.

Loras has renounced his title and claims on Highgarden long ago, when he joined the Kingsguard. In any case, his elder brother Willas is the heir to Highgarden. Loras never said Renly was a traitor.

Members of the Faith Militant are not required to carve the seven-pointed star onto their foreheads. It is sufficient for them to paint the star on their brows or sew a badge of it to their clothes. Only the zealous among them carve the star into their chests, not their foreheads.

Scene: The Mountain blocks Tommen from going to the trial
Lancel suspects something
Comparison: In the books, Kevan, not Pycelle or Lancel, is lured to a death trap by one of the Little Birds.

Scene: Maester Pycelle is killed by Qyburn's little birds
Comparison:
In the books, Varys, not Qyburn, murders Pycelle. The murder occurs off-screen. Pycelle does not die as a result of multiple stab wounds. Instead, his skull is bashed.

Kevan, not Pycelle or Lancel, is lured to a death trap by one of the Little Birds.
Kevan is fatally injured by an arrow Varys shoots at him. Varys apologizes, explaining why it was necessary to kill him and Pycelle, then Kevan is finished off by the Little Birds.

Scene: The Sept of Baelor is blown up
Comparison:
Lord Walder Frey, Lothar, Walder Rivers, Black Walder, Mace Tyrell, Margaery Tyrell, Loras Tyrell, Lancel, Tommen and the High Sparrow are still alive.

Cersei has the Tower of the Hand, not the Great Sept of Baelor, destroyed by wildfire. It happens towards the beginning of A Feast for Crows; no one is harmed as a result.

Scene: Cersei hands Septa Unella over to Ser Gregor Clegane
Tommen jumps
Comparison: In the books, Tommen is still alive.

Scene: Walder Frey gloats over taking over Riverrun
Comparison: In the books, after the siege of Riverrun is resolved, Edmure is sent to Casterly Rock, not back to the Twins.

Scene: Cersei decides Tommen's funeral
Sam and Gilly arrive at the Citadel
Comparison:
In the books, Sam does not bring Gilly and the baby to the Citadel.

Sam waits for hours until he is admitted to speak with the archmaester. He is first approached by a novice named Alleras, who is interested in hearing Sam's story, then is taken to the archmaester.

No one inquires Sam about the current Lord Commander of the Night's Watch.

Scene: Sam is in awe of the library
Davos confronts Melisandre about Shireen
Comparison: In the books, Davos never said he loved Shireen like she was his own daughter.

Scene: Jon and Sansa chat
Comparison: The white raven is sent to King's Landing, not Winterfell.

Scene: Lady Olenna and the Sand Snakes plan their vengeance
Comparison:
In the books, the Tyrells are still alive.

Arianne Martell, not Olenna, asks her father, "What is our heartâ€™s desire?" Doran, not Ellaria and Varys, answers, "Vengeance, justice, fire and blood."

Scene: Daenerys leaves Daario behind in Meeren
Comparison: In the books, Daario is the commander of the Stormcrows, not the Second Sons.

Scene: Daenerys names Tyrion the Hand of the Queen
Arya serves Walder Frey some pies
Comparison:
The Freys who are killed and baked in a pie are not Black Walder and Lothar. Jared, Rhaegar and Symond Frey disappear on their way from White Harbor to Winterfell; it is likely that they were baked into pies on the orders of Lord Wyman Manderly, but it has not been confirmed yet. Arya, who is still in Braavos at that point, has nothing to do with their deaths.

The pies are brought to Ramsay's wedding, not to the Twins. Lord Frey does not attend the wedding, therefore does not eat the pies, but his third and sixth sons Aenys and Hosteen do. They are not told afterwards what the pies are made of. Of the Freys who ate from the pies, only Aenys is killed. Arya has nothing to do with his death.

Scene: Petyr declares himself for Sansa
Comparison:
In the books, Sansa never came to the godswood to pray to be somewhere else.

Littlefinger never stated he wanted the Iron Throne. His plans, as far as he revealed to Sansa, are to take over the Vale and Winterfell by marrying her to Harrold Hardyng.

Scene: Benjen parts ways with Bran near the Wall
Comparison: Sam explains why Coldhands cannot pass beyond the Wall.

Scene: Bran sees what happened in the tower in his vision
Comparison: Jon Snow's parentage is as of yet unconfirmed in the books.

Scene: Jon is proclaimed King in the North
Comparison:
House Glover always supported the Starks. Cley Cerwyn is long dead, killed by the Boltons.

It is not Lyanna Mormont but Wylla, Lord Manderly's granddaughter, who speaks in favor of the Starks. Davos, not Lyanna Mormont, reminds Lord Manderly of his son's death at the Red Wedding. Lord Manderly and Robett Glover declare their loyalty to the Starks only in private, in front of Davos.

Lord Manderly is described as so obese that he cannot ride a horse, leading to his nickname, "Lord Too Fat To Sit A Horse".

Scene: Cersei is crowned Queen
Comparison: In the books, Jaime does not go to the Twins after resolving the siege of Riverrun, but to Raventree Hall. So far he has not returned to King's Landing.

Scene: Daenerys sails west
